Module lanat
Package lanat

Class CommandTemplate

java.lang.Object
lanat.CommandTemplate
Direct Known Subclasses:
CommandTemplate.Default
public abstract class CommandTemplate extends Object

Command Template

Define the arguments and attributes of a command by defining the structure of a class.

Creating a Template

In order to define a new Command Template, create a new class that extends CommandTemplate and annotate it with Command.Define. The class must be public and static.

A Command Template can inherit from another Command Template, which will also inherit the arguments and sub-commands of the parent. Command Templates are initialized from the parent to the child, so the parent's arguments will be initialized before the child's.

Example: 

 @Command.Define(description = "My cool program")
 public class MyProgram extends CommandTemplate {
   // ...
 }

Defining the Arguments

To define an argument that will belong to the command, create a public field with the type that the parsed argument value should be. Annotate it with Argument.Define.

The name of the argument may be specified in the annotation with the Argument.Define.names() parameter. If no name is specified, the name of the field will be used.

The type of the argument may be specified in the annotation with the Argument.Define.type() parameter. If an ArgumentType subclass is specified, it must have a public, no-argument constructor. If the Argument Type to use has a constructor with arguments, the type must be then specified in beforeInit(CommandBuildContext) instead, by setting ArgumentBuilder.type(ArgumentType) to the argument builder corresponding to the argument being defined.

If a class that does not subclass ArgumentType is specified on the annotation, or simply none is specified, the Argument Type will be attempted to be inferred from the field/annotation type if possible. (See ArgumentTypeInfer)

Example: 

 @Command.Define
 public class ParentCommand extends CommandTemplate {
   @Argument.Define(names = {"name", "n"}, type = String.class) // type: StringArgumentType
   public String name;

   @Argument.Define // name: "numbers". type: TupleArgumentType<Integer>
   public Integer[] numbers;

   @Argument.Define(required = true) // name: "file". type: NumberRangeArgumentType<Integer>
   public Integer number;

   @InitDef
   public static void beforeInit(CommandBuildContext ctx) {
      // set the argument type to NumberRangeArgumentType
      ctx.argWithType("number", new NumberRangeArgumentType<>(0, 10));
   }
 }

Defining Sub-Commands

To define a sub-command, create a new inner class inside the parent Command Template class already defined (with same rules as for any Command Template class). Then, create a public field in the parent command template class with the type of the sub-command Command Template just created. Annotate it with CommandTemplate.CommandAccessor. This will properly link the sub-command to the parent command when the parent command is initialized.

Example: 

 @Command.Define
 public class ParentCommand extends CommandTemplate {
   @CommandAccessor
   public SubCommand subCommand;

   public static class SubCommand extends CommandTemplate {
      // ...
   }
 }

Other actions

In order to configure the command more precisely, two public static methods with the CommandTemplate.InitDef annotation may be defined in the Command Template class:

  • beforeInit(CommandBuildContext): Called before adding the Arguments to the Command.
  • afterInit(Command): Called after the Command is initialized.
See Also:

    • getParseResult

      @NotNull public final @NotNull ParseResult getParseResult()
      Returns the ParseResult instance used by this Command Template. This instance is the one that was used to initialize this Command Template.
      Returns:
      The ParseResult instance used by this Command Template.

    • getCommand

      @NotNull public final @NotNull Command getCommand()
      Returns the Command instance used by this Command Template. This instance is the one that was used to initialize this Command Template.
      Returns:
      The Command instance used by this Command Template.

    • wasUsed

      public final boolean wasUsed()
      Returns true if the Command of this Template was used in the command line.
      Returns:
      true if the Command of this Template was used in the command line, false otherwise.

    • onUsed

      public void onUsed(@NotNull @NotNull ParseResult parseResult)
      Called when the Command of this Template is used in the command line. This method is called after the parsed values are set.

      This method may be overridden to perform actions when the command is used.

      This method should not be called manually. It is called automatically by the Argument Parser once the Command Template is initialized.

    • getTemplateNames

      @NotNull public static @NotNull String @NotNull [] getTemplateNames(@NotNull @NotNull Class<? extends CommandTemplate> cmdTemplate)
      Returns the names of the command template. If no names are specified in the annotation, the simple name of the class will be used. Note: Expects the field to be annotated with Command.Define
      Parameters:
      cmdTemplate - The command template class. Must be annotated with Command.Define.
      Returns:
      The names of the command template.

    • beforeInit

      public static void beforeInit(@NotNull CommandTemplate.CommandBuildContext ctx)
      This method is called after the Command Template builder reads all the field arguments defined. This is before the arguments are instantiated and finally added to the command.

      Example: 

      
 @Command.Define
 public class ParentCommand extends CommandTemplate {
   @Argument.Define
   public Integer numberRange;

   @InitDef
   public static void beforeInit(CommandBuildContext ctx) {
      // set the argument type to NumberRangeArgumentType
      ctx.argWithType("numberRange", new NumberRangeArgumentType<>(0, 10));
   }
 }
      Parameters:
      ctx - A helper object that contains the command being initialized and the list of argument builders that may be altered.

    • afterInit

      public static void afterInit(@NotNull @NotNull Command cmd)
      This method is called after the Command is initialized. This is after the Arguments are instantiated and added to the command. This method may be used to perform actions after the command is finally ready to be parsed. Actions such as creating groups of arguments, for example.
      Parameters:
      cmd - The command that was fully initialized.

    • afterInit

      public static void afterInit(@NotNull @NotNull ArgumentParser cmd)
